qas.question: What other contemporaneous school of thought is often confused with Popper's own contributions?
Popper has stressed that his description of scientific methodology should not be mistaken to apply to whom?
At what level does Popper indicate his view of scientific methodology applies?
What kind of progress does science make given the methodology Popper describes?
What does Popper argue is therefore true?
Whose ideas are a logical account of truth?
What did not appear at the same time as Popper's ideas?
What did the followers of logical positivism mistake as opposite to their own?
What kind of progress does science make if it does not use Popper's methodology?

context: He does not argue that any such <b4_0>conclusions<b4_0/> are therefore true, or that this describes the actual methods of <a1_0>any particular scientist<a1_0/>.[citation needed] Rather, it is recommended as an essential principle of methodology that, if enacted by a <a2_0>system or community<a2_0/>, will lead to <a3_0><b8_0>slow but steady<b8_0/><a3_0/> progress of a sort (relative to how well the system or community enacts the method). It has been suggested that <b5_0>Popper's<b5_0/> ideas are often mistaken for a hard logical account of truth because of the historical co-incidence of their appearing at the same time as <a0_0><b6_0>logical positivism<b6_0/><a0_0/>, the followers of which mistook <b7_0>his aims<b7_0/> for their own.
